:sweat_smile:
anyone here familiar with IdlingResource?
whats up
I thought I would be able to register them at any time
but all the examples show them in `@Before` methods
when else would you?
I was hoping to write a test like:
yep, you register them before you start your tests
click something, wait for idling resource, click something else
I’m not sure it works like you think it does
I’m writing a test to take screenshots if that context helps at all
ok, well basically - espresso waits until an app is idle before performing an operation
and it waits for two things
ui events in the message queue
and tasks in the asynctask thread pool
if the thing you want espresso to wait for is not one of those (maybe some sort of background job, etc)
you need to tell espresso to wait for it
via IdlingResource
make sense?
one sec, digesting that lol
:simple_smile:
I guess what’s confusing me is how would a test be at the point where the idling resource part happens first?
isn’t that generally a reaction to a UI click?
for example, if you run an async request through your network queue, you don’t know when the response returns and triggers a ui event

espresso automatically looks at two things, main thread, and the async thread pool. if you create any other async threads or your network stack uses it’s own, then the idlelistener attaches to them before the tests start so espresso can wait on all events to complete before continuing the next action
what do you mean by `idling resource part happens first`
you’re saying that Espresso waits for the idling resources to finish before performing the test, right?
which appears to be the case since mine keep timing out
no
not before performing the test
before performing an action
ah
so like
you can wrap your network request thing (maybe volley) in an IdlingResource
so the flow is something like
espresso presses the load button
network requests happening
er
if you DONT use idling resource
espresso wont wait for it to come back
and it will then continue, and likely fail, because the data isnt loaded
I see, that makes more sense
if you wrap your network or whatever calls in IdlingResource
it will wait til they are done
THEN make assertions, etc.
damn, it doesn’t seem like I can use IdlingResource for my screenshots usecase then
what’s the case you’re running into?
I don’t understand
I’m essentially writing one long test case to manually step through and screenshot my app
Just write an Espresso action to take the screenshots
or use UiAutomator
^ this
the flow is press button -> wait for network call -> click something else -> wait for another network call -> etc
ok
so
and originally I thought I could wait for idling resources at each of those “wait for network call” steps
Use IR for the network calls
you should
you _have_ to
and THEN
use something like
<http://developer.android.com/intl/es/reference/android/support/test/uiautomator/UiDevice.html#takeScreenshot(java.io.File)>
to take a screenshot
espresso doesn’t know when those requests complete because it doesn’t have access to your network request queue
but thats orthogonal to taking a screenshot
the screenshot part I already have covered
but I still don’t see how IR will work here, since the network call isn’t triggered until after the first action I take
so it will always time out waiting for that IR to finish
why
IR doesn’t care
it’s not
the IR is the listener for your network request queue essentially
you said `before performing an action`
so if my first action is clicking a button
but I’ve already registered my IR
it might time out
exactly
after a few seconds, dunno what the default is
then it’s going to wait since the network call is triggered as a result of that action
so you register the IR once, before the tests start

create a IR for your network stack(volley, retrofit, etc) and register that before your tests run. then as your tests run, espresso is able to determine the appropriate time to perform the next action
this prevents clicking on inactive elements, or non-existent elements
and then timing out
I actually don’t think it times out by default
unless the timeout is a long time
true, it’ll probably just fail
I think one minute is the default timeout iirc
yeah maybe. I never have run into it
